docs.lead_paragraph: Henry Harris had a new girlfriend, and it was beginning to get serious. So last summer, Mr. Harris, 24, a high school safety officer from Brooklyn, decided it was time to be tested for H.I.V. and other sexually transmitted diseases. ''If two people are going to get together in this day and age,'' he said, matter-of-factly, ''you really need to make sure everybody is clean.''

headline.main: Men's Reproductive Health Care Gets New Emphasis

docs.abstract: Article on, Young Men's Clinic, joint project of Columbia University's Mailman School of Public Health and New York Presbyterian Hospital, which offers free medical care, including physicals, to low income men and those lacking health insurance; director David Bell says center's main goal is sexual health needs of young men, who have high rates of sexually transmitted diseases; photo; graphs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Hospitals and insurance companies can readily obtain information about a physician's malpractice claims, but in most states the public cannot. But in at least 15 states, the Federation of State Medical Boards says, some such records are available on official Web sites. Physician groups in most states oppose the practice. Gale Scott discussed the issue with the presidents of two medical societies. These are edited excerpts of those interviews. YES. The Massachusetts Board of Registration in Medicine began its Physician Profiles Project in 1996. The project has resulted in a Web site where visitors can get information about paid malpractice claims along with a physician's business and professional demographics, education and training, hospital affiliations and the insurance plans accepted. If the doctor has had disciplinary actions or a criminal history that will also be online.

headline.main: The Place for Public Documents: On File or Online?

docs.abstract: Excerpts from interviews with Massachusetts Medical Society president Francis X Rockett and Illinois State Medical Society president Ronald L Rucker, in which they take opposing views on whether information about malpractice claims against physicians should be made available on the Internet; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It could be called ''The Case of the Coffee-Break Poisoner.'' No one died, but 12 men who worked in an auto factory in the Midwest were hospitalized, and the incident holds lessons for emergency-room doctors in the difficulty of diagnosing poisonings, a case report says. The article, published in The Annals of Emergency Medicine, described the incident as ''the largest reported case series of criminal thallium poisoning in the United States.''
docs.abstract: Report published in Annals of Emergency Medicine describes incident in which 12 men who worked in auto factory in Midwest were poisoned by thallium and arsenic put in coffeepot, containers of sugar and creamer and in coffee grounds; men all recovered but no arrests were made; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: People worried about Lyme disease have long been told to keep an eye out for a bull's-eye rash -- a red circle with a pale center. But a new study suggests that this advice may need revision. The study, published today in The Annals of Internal Medicine, found the first sign of Lyme disease was usually a rash whose center was as red or redder than the rest. ''The main point is that the rash can have a variety of appearances -- clinicians can't rely entirely on looking for the textbook version,'' the lead author of the study, Dr. Robert P. Smith of the Maine Medical Center in Portland, said in an interview.

headline.main: The Not-So-Telltale Sign of Lyme Disease

docs.abstract: New study published in Annals of Internal Medicine finds that first sign of Lyme disease is rash whose center is red or redder than rest rather than red bull's-eye rash with pale center; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: . Eyedrops can work as well as an eyepatch in correcting moderate amblyopia, commonly called lazy eye, in children, a new study has concluded.

headline.main: An Easier Aid for a Lazy Eye

docs.abstract: Johns Hopkins Wilmer Eye Institute study concludes that eyedrops work as well as eye patch in correctiong moderate amblyopia, or lazy, eye, in children; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Managed care plans in California will be required to refer H.I.V. patients to doctors certified as AIDS specialists under regulations scheduled to take effect in July, making the state the first to impose such a requirement on private health insurers. Studies have shown that H.I.V. patients fare best when treated by doctors who have experience with the virus. But there is no broadly accepted definition of what constitutes expertise in H.I.V., so health plans have generally been left to devise their own standards, which vary widely.

headline.main: California Is Tightening Rules on H.I.V. Care

docs.abstract: California, first state to impose such regulations, will require managed care plans, beginning in July, to refer HIV patients to doctors certified as AIDS specialists; AIDS advocates applaud new rules and expect them to influence debate in other states; photo (M)

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: For women, a little alcohol -- say, two or three drinks a week -- seems to lower the risk of developing high blood pressure, while more -- two drinks a day or more -- seems to raise it, according to a new study. ''There has been very good evidence that four drinks a more a day can lead to high blood pressure, but the question has been what happens below that,'' said Dr. Eric B. Rimm of the Harvard School of Public Health, one of the authors of a study published last week in The Archives of Internal Medicine.

headline.main: Raising a Glass or Two to Better Health

docs.abstract: Dr Eric B Rimm of Harvard School of Public Health and others publish study in Archives of Internal Medicine concluding that women who drink two or three drinks a week seem to have lower risk of developing high blood pressure while two drinks a day or more seems to raise risk (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When the first jet hit the north tower of the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, my patient Alan was in his office on the 81st floor of the south tower. He remembers the blue sky turning white with a rain of paper and debris. And within minutes, the sight of people jumping to their deaths was burned into his memory. Alan is a chronic worrier, always tense and anxious. So he was not reassured when he heard the announcement that his tower was safe and that he should stay put. Instinctively, he fled, running down all 81 flights of stairs.
docs.abstract: Dr Richard A Friedman Cases column on patient with lifelong generalized anxiety disorder who witnessed, from his office on 81st floor of south tower, attacks on World Trade Center and experienced full fear reaction whenever stimulated by crashing sounds or burning smells; describes cognitive-behavioral therapy that is lessening fear reaction but not traumatic memories; addresses question of type of memorial that would be appropriate at site (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Men over 60 who took aspirin or another anti-inflammatory drug daily were half as likely as those who didn't to be diagnosed with prostate cancer during a six-year Mayo Clinic study. The gap was even larger among men over 70, according to an article published last week in The Mayo Clinic Proceedings.

headline.main: Another Possible Aspirin Benefit for Men

docs.abstract: Article published in Mayo Clinic Proceedings finds that men over 60 who take aspirin or other anti-inflammatory drug daily are half as likely than those who do not to be diagnosed with prostate cancer (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Just because a medication once sold only by prescription is now available over the counter does not mean that patients know how and when to use it properly. A good example involves the antifungal products now sold without prescriptions for the treatment of vaginitis -- not just any vaginitis, but the most common form, caused by the ubiquitous yeast of the genus Candida. The fine print on the back of the box of the leading product, Monistat 3, warns, ''Do not use if you have never had a vaginal yeast infection diagnosed by a doctor.'' That is meant to ensure that a woman who walks into a drugstore with a self-diagnosis will know that she indeed has a vaginal yeast infection and not something else -- something potentially more serious -- for which this product is inappropriate.

headline.main: Yeast Infection: The Pitfalls of Self-Diagnosis

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column on findings of study directed by Dr Daron G Ferris of Medical College of Georgia, published in March issue of Obstetrics and Gynecology, showing that only one third of women buying over-the-counter vaginal antifungal product Monistat 3 accurately self-diagnosed their conditions; graph (M)
